commits.message: Move <selfcontained> property to csproj instead of setting in Nuke

Disable globalization requirements in dd-trace tool (#4721)

Include Datadog.Trace in our root-descriptors file (#4723)

* Add Datadog.Trace to the root descriptors file
Remove debug mode (#4728)

[TESTS] Segregate samples logs (#4698)

* Segregated test logs in different folders

Revert "Revert "[DSM ] - Lag metrics support (#4574)" (#4704)" (#4720)

This reverts commit e67b62974ab10a3014723b9c02af28ed2d6e361b.
nit: stop CopyNativeFilesForAppSecUnitTests doing so much work (#4724)
[IAST][BUGFIX] Cleanup source and evidence null chars (#4733)
Diagnostic tool improvements (#4725)

[CI Visibility] - BenchmarkDotNet + Datadog Profiler  (#4650)

* Initial implementation

* Changes

* fixes

* Fix profiler tests

* restore default upload period.

* Increase accuracy by increasing the collection rate of the profiler.

* Add `DD_CIVISIBILITY_ENABLED` environment variable in the profiler.

* Fix tests

* Fix tests

* Changes from review

* fixes

* Improve tagging

* fix

* Moar tags

* Add _dd.origin: ciapp-test to the profiles.

* - Reduce profiles numbers
- Remove origin tag
- Hide WithDatadog + Profiler overload.

---------

Co-authored-by: Gregory LEOCADIE <gregory.leocadie@datadoghq.com>

Update native build to use `/FS` option (#4718)

* Add FS to Datadog.Tracer.Native C++ files

Make `compare_throughput` stage more robust (#4739)

* Always upload throughput results with the same name

This solves problems around retrying throughput tests

* Don't crash the compare_throughput stage if some results aren't available
Fix flaky DSM test (#4741)

Merge `throughput_appsec` into `throughput` stage (#4740)

Handle very long type names in duck typing (#4756)
Use dd-dotnet in dd-trace (#4732)

Removed unneeded virtual clause
Minor fixes

issue.title: Add support for NLog 5.2.5
issue.body:
## Summary of changes

Adds support for the latest point release of NLog

## Reason for change

[Internal refactoring of the NLog code in 5.2.5](https://github.com/NLog/NLog/compare/v5.2.4...v5.2.5#diff-79da5f592484e013a16966f309a0ecb9affca55b723e288b31db1b88e8005244L597) broke some of the key methods we rely on

## Implementation details

The method signature of `LogFactory.BuildLoggerConfiguration()` changed, which broke our integration. It also fundamentally breaks the approach we were taking (creating a `LoggingConfiguration` if one wasn't provided), because of changes to how it works.

_Technically_ we _could_ still create the `LoggingConfiguration` and set it on the `BuildLoggerConfiguration`. But I'm not sure if we should or want to do that. The current implementation works for our tests, so that's _probably_ good enough

## Test coverage

Updated to the latest version, but otherwise covered by existing tests. 
I ran a complete (all frameworks, all package versions) test for NLog [here](https://dev.azure.com/datadoghq/dd-trace-dotnet/_build/results?buildId=146633&view=results) and all good :+1:

## Other details
There was a minor bug in the csproj of NLog breaking the 4.x packages on linux. This was unrelated to my fix, but included here because I had to fix it to do the full package test

pull_request.title: [Tracing] Fix WebRequest bug with existing distributed tracing headers
pull_request.body:
## Summary of changes
When we pre-emptively add distributed tracing headers in `WebRequest.BeginGetRequestStream`, `WebRequest.BeginGetResponse`, and `WebRequest.GetRequestStream`, add the headers to a cache to signal to the later integrations that we had last updated the headers and we are responsible for the distributed tracing headers in the WebRequest object.

When we check for the pre-emptively added distributed tracing headers in `WebRequest.EndGetResponse`, `WebRequest.GetResponse` and `WebRequest.GetResponseAsync`, first check a cache to know whether we added distributed tracing headers to the WebRequest object. If present, then continue to use the injected trace context. Otherwise, we create a new context.

## Reason for change
In our `GetResponse` integrations, we check the WebRequest headers to see if we had to pre-emptively add distributed tracing headers before the headers became locked, and if they are present then we use that context for the newly created WebRequest span.

The problem with this, as seen in a user issue, is that some applications may proxy incoming headers to the outbound HTTP requests. Before this change, our handling would cause our integrations for `WebRequest.EndGetResponse`, `WebRequest.GetResponse`, and `WebRequest.GetResponseAsync` to re-use the trace context in the headers for the WebRequest span, which results in the server span and the outgoing HTTP span having the same trace-id and span-id. After the fix, we only re-use the trace context when we know that we had last updated the headers.

## Implementation details
For our cache, we use (surprise!) a ConditionalWeakTable to keep track of request headers that we injected a trace context into. We use this data structure because it will remove stale entries when the keys are no longer referenced. In the `GetResponse` integrations we only use the trace context from the request headers if our automatic instrumentation had injected the headers.

## Test coverage
Update the WebRequest test application to manually add distributed tracing headers, and rewrite the integration tests to collect all spans from the application and assert that there are no duplicate trace-id/span-id combinations. Before the product change, we would see duplicates from the `GetResponse` and `GetResponseAsync` calls.

## Other details
N/A

review.body:
I think I'm slightly confused by this:
- AFAICT, we always overwrite any manually-added spans by injecting our own.
- In that case, shouldn't it always be safe to use the headers we find?

I'm assuming there's some edge case where we _don't_ inject the headers, but I'm not sure what that is?

Also, this is a "bad practice" by the customer right, it feels like in an OTel world this would be a great way to get some really weird traces too?

pull_request.title: [serverless][SVLS-579] Add span error metadata to DD Lambda Extension request headers
pull_request.body: ## Summary of changes Extracts the span tags `error.msg`, `error.type` and `error.stack` and sends them to the Lambda Extension via request headers. Part of changes made in the Extension: https://github.com/DataDog/datadog-agent/pull/20235 ## Reason for change In a Lambda environment, if error span tags are explicitly set they're never received by the execution span created in the Extension. By sending error tags via request headers, we can create the `aws.lambda` span with correct error metadata ## Implementation details Checks the active span for `error.*` tags and adds them to request headers to the `/lambda/end-invocation` endpoint. ## Test coverage Added unit tests ## Other details

pull_request.title: [Tracer] Elasticsearch Refactor Part 1 (AIT-8764)
pull_request.body:
## Summary of changes
Sets up snapshot testing for Elasticsearch and removes the use of Elasticsearch path as a fallback value for the resource name

## Reason for change
The main motivation was to see if we could remove the Elasticsearch path as a fallback since the RequestParameters should always be present, and the snapshot tests were added to validate the before/after.

## Implementation details
- Removes the Elasticsearch path as a fallback value for the resource name
- Refactors the RequestData proxies since the duck type shapes are now consistent between library major versions
- Adds snapshot testing with normalization of the service name and the Elasticsearch host name

## Test coverage
Added snapshot testing

## Other details
Part 1 implies a Part 2 😆 With snapshot testing, I want to try a refactor to guarantee that we always have the command name. This can be done in a follow-up PR in case it is unsuccessful

pull_request.title: [Tracer] Elasticsearch Refactor Part 1 (AIT-8764)
pull_request.body:
## Summary of changes
Sets up snapshot testing for Elasticsearch and removes the use of Elasticsearch path as a fallback value for the resource name

## Reason for change
The main motivation was to see if we could remove the Elasticsearch path as a fallback since the RequestParameters should always be present, and the snapshot tests were added to validate the before/after.

## Implementation details
- Removes the Elasticsearch path as a fallback value for the resource name
- Refactors the RequestData proxies since the duck type shapes are now consistent between library major versions
- Adds snapshot testing with normalization of the service name and the Elasticsearch host name

## Test coverage
Added snapshot testing

## Other details
Part 1 implies a Part 2 😆 With snapshot testing, I want to try a refactor to guarantee that we always have the command name. This can be done in a follow-up PR in case it is unsuccessful

review.body: Awesome, thanks! I didn't scrutinize the snapshots too closely, but they LGTM. The only potential issue may be flakiness around sort-order. I think we'll need to update the span order to sort by resource name and elasticsearch.url tag

## Execution-Time Benchmarks Report :stopwatch:

Execution-time results for samples comparing the following branches/commits:
- [This PR (4773)](https://github.com/DataDog/dd-trace-dotnet/tree/8d54992473266c2c6a328f42a5cddf228d8cd092)
- [master](https://github.com/DataDog/dd-trace-dotnet/tree/8c23d88d614badec53276220cea456901c9dcca7)

Execution-time benchmarks measure the whole time it takes to execute a program. And are intended to measure the one-off costs. Cases where the execution time results for the PR are worse than latest master results are shown in **red**. The following thresholds were used for comparing the execution times:
* Welch test with statistical test for significance of **5%**
* Only results indicating a difference greater than **5%** and **5 ms** are considered.


Note that these results are based on a _single_ point-in-time result for each branch. For full results, see the [dashboard](https://ddstaging.datadoghq.com/dashboard/4qn-6fi-54p/apm-net-execution-time-benchmarks).

Graphs show the p99 interval based on the mean and StdDev of the test run, as well as the mean value of the run (shown as a diamond below the graph).

* bump

* fix

* Increase iterations

Update querystring obfuscationregex (2) (#4764)

* change obf. regex

* update unit tests

* remove useless flags

[ASM] Update IAST source names (#4755)

* Source name change

* update telemetry tags

* fix source names

* update telemetry snapshots

Update package versions prior to adding .NET 8 support

This is purely to make it easier to isolate the .NET8 related version updates later.

Update CI and global.json to use the .NET SDK to use 8.0.100-rc.2

This was done in several commits and subsequently squashed

Add .NET 8 support to Nuke

- Add TargetFramework.NET8_0
- Add .NET 8.0 to the standard list of tested frameworks (replaces .NET 7.0 in PRs)
- Added extension for doing easier GreaterThan() comparisons with TargetFramework (only works for .NET Framework)

Allow building Nuke against .NET 7 but running against .NET 8

Add smoke tests for .NET 8 images

The chiseled containers are commented out currently because they don't work with
our dockerfiles (because you can't run _any_ shell commands, e.g. mkdir).
We can add these back in a subsequent PR

Update test projects to support testing against net8.0

Adds additional Sqlite references to Security.AspNetCore5 to resolve version-conflicts in restore graph

Update variable generation to use debian in the integration tests (to support .NET 8)

Update some `#if NET7_0` to `#if NET7_0_OR_GREATER`

We should always use the `_OR_GREATER` versions where possible, as makes upgrades easier

Generate .NET 8 package version targets for integration tests

- Note that this doesn't add support for any _new_ package versions, just ensures we test existing supported versions on .NET 8 too.
- By favoring "exclude TFM" over "include TFM" in PackageVersionsGeneratorDefinitions.json, this didn't require many changes :)
Update integrations for built-in packages to support .NET 8

Fix a breaking change in DuckTyping support

Pre-.NET 8, we use reflection to invoke the private member `MethodBuilder.GetToken()`.
However, in .NET 8 they moved a bunch of reflection emit APIs around:
https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/78544
The net result is that the `GetToken()` method no longer exists. Luckily, the public
`MetadataToken` property directly calls `GetToken()`, so we can use that instead.

For the fix, we add a fallback for looking for that token. Theoretically, at some point in the future, we could switch the order (when/if .NET 8+ becomes the most common FX)

Turn off NuGet audit so that we can actually build

- Otherwise it complains about .NET Core 2.1 and a multitude of issues, and means we can't build
- For the Exploration tests we have to pass the flag at runtime as we clone the repos fresh
Add missing EOL exemptions
